title: Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' is a Solid Effort
summary: The lead single off of the album, “Short Hair,” is a very catchy and fun pop track. The title track, Voicenotes, is “inspired by what [he] went through” and that “the emotions and the feelings” were his inspiration. Puth also teamed up with frequent collaborator Shawn Mendes for a song called “Change My Life” It’s a great collaboration that shows that Puth and Mendes are both on their way to becoming superstars.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Bad for Me is a bassy and groovy pop song with a killer chorus and great rhythm, while How Long is more of a ballad with a very Puth-ian piano. Both are a great taste of the album, and they are already off to a great start.")),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Puth has said that the title track, Voicenotes, is \u201Cinspired by what ","[he]"," went through,\u201D and that \u201Cthe emotions and the feelings\u201D were his inspiration. \u201CIt\u2019s about making a change in your life. You\u2019ve got to change the way you look at things,\u201D and he truly manages to create an uplifting and inspiring track.")),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Puth also teamed up with frequent collaborator Shawn Mendes for a song called \u201CChange My Life.\u201D It\u2019s a very catchy, bouncy pop song, and it\u2019s one of the strongest tracks on the album."))),mdx("h2",null,"Charlie Puth\u2019s growth as an artist"),mdx("p",null,"Puth has proven that he\u2019s not just a one-hit wonder, and that\u2019s always a good sign. There are still strong pop hooks throughout all of these songs, but he\u2019s exploring different textures and different feels. He\u2019s growing as an artist, and it\u2019s a really nice progression to see."),mdx("p",null,"Puth also seems to be growing as a songwriter. These songs are less endearing and more mature than those on his previous two albums. The lyrics of Voicenotes are a bit darker, and they\u2019re more real. You can feel the emotion behind each song, and it feels like Puth has really put himself out there."),mdx("h2",null,"Voice Notes: Title track and lead single"),mdx("p",null,"Voicenotes is the first track on the album, and it is a beautiful and breathy acoustic pop song. Puth\u2019s voice is particularly strong here, and the chorus is an absolute banger. The lyrics are contemplative and are reminiscent of an adult journal or a letter to someone close to the writer. Puth has said that the song is intended to be a love song, and that it was written while he was in a relationship. It\u2019s a very personal song, and it\u2019s a great way to kick off the album."),mdx("p",null,"The lead single off of the album, \u201CShort Hair,\u201D is a very catchy and fun pop track. It\u2019s a bit more upbeat than many of the songs on the album, and it\u2019s a great choice for a lead single. It\u2019s a very lighthearted and fun track that is also very catchy, and it\u2019s a great introduction to Puth\u2019s latest album."),mdx("h2",null,"Nine Track Mind"),mdx("p",null,"\u201CNine Track Mind\u201D is the seventh track off of Voicenotes. The chorus is dreamy and gorgeous, and it is one of my favorite tracks off of the album."),mdx("p",null,"The title and chorus make a play on the \u201C8-track\u201D sound system that was popular in the 70s and 80s, while Puth\u2019s voice and tone are perfect for this laid-back and dreamy track. Shawn Mendes)"),mdx("p",null,"\u201CChange My Life\u201D is the 14th track on the album. It is a very catchy, upbeat track, with a light and airy tone. Despite the fact that it has a light tone, the track is very deep and meaningful, with Puth and Mendes singing about finding someone who can save them. It\u2019s a very sweet, meaningful track, and it\u2019s another one of my favorites on the album."),mdx("p",null,"The track is a very strong collaboration, and it\u2019s a great track that shows two artists who are both on their way to becoming superstars. It\u2019s a bit more experimental, and it\u2019s a very different sound from most of the rest of the album. It\u2019s a very different track, and it\u2019s one that I personally love."),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s another track that feels very real, and it\u2019s a very interesting track that\u2019s worth listening to even if you don\u2019t usually go for this type of music. The chemistry and dynamic between Steinfeld and Puth is really interesting, and this track is a great example of the two of them working together."),mdx("h2",null,"Fool\u2019s Gold"),mdx("p",null,"\u201CFool\u2019s Gold\u201D is the 37th track on the album. It has a bit of a darker tone, but it\u2019s still a very light track, and it\u2019s very easy to listen to."),mdx("p",null,"This is another track that I really like, and it\u2019s a great way to end the album. relatedArticles.title: "Boyhood" Is a Coming-Of-Age Story like No Other

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The coming-of-age trope is one of the most frequently used narrative devices in modern film. From "Stand by Me" to "Superbad," there are countless stories about adolescents transitioning from innocent children into independent adults. However, it is almost unheard of for a film to capture the nuances and absurdities of growing up as effectively as Richard Linklater\u2019s \u201CBoyhood.\u201D The movie documents 12 years in the life of Mason (played by Ellar Coltrane) and his family through a series of carefully crafted vignettes that document the everyday minutiae of life without being clich\xE9 or cloying.
Like so many movies about kids growing up, "Boyhood" begins with young Mason being uprooted from his home in Texas and forced to migrate to new cities as he grows older. What makes this movie unique, however, is that all these major events occur over an 11-year period while Linklater was filming with the same actors at different points in their lives. The result is something like a documentary on human development \u2014 funny, sad, awkward, and everything in between \u2014 presented through the lens of an intimate cinematic experience.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Father John Misty's 'Pure Comedy' Is a Hilarious Masterpiece
Death Cab for Cutie's 'Thank You for Today' Is a Delight

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Thank You for Today is the sixth album from Seattle indie rockers Death Cab for Cutie. Released on August 31, 2018, it\u2019s also the band\u2019s final record with their original label Atlantic Records. After two decades in the music business, Death Cab for Cutie have developed into one of the most beloved bands in indie rock.
After their last album, Codes and Keys (2012), frontman Ben Gibbard announced that he was working on a solo project called The New Age. It was something he had been thinking about for some time but wasn\u2019t sure when or if it would come to fruition. Fortunately, after meeting with producer Rich Costey (M83, Blond Redhead) who helped him record some demos, things fell into place. The album came out as a collaborative release between Ben Gibbard and Nathan Wiley under the name The Further Adventures of New Age. And three years later Death Cab For Cutie released Thank You For Today.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Rappers That Will Make You Want to Get Out on the Floor and Dance

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"As hip-hop continues to shed its once-maligned reputation and become increasingly popular, we\u2019ve seen a related boom in mainstream rap music. More than ever before, people are listening to and talking about rappers. But with so much of the genre becoming commodified and predictable, it can be difficult for new artists to stand out among the noise. Fortunately, just because most popular rap fails to break any molds doesn\u2019t mean that the genre is completely devoid of creative talent. In fact, there are a number of rappers who have been working hard to maintain their integrity while still appealing to a larger audience. If you\u2019re ready to put on your dancing shoes and get out on the floor with one of these 10 amazing rappers who will make you want to dance:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Big Short" Is a Searing Indictment of the Financial Industry

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The film version of The Big Short hits theaters this Friday, and it\u2019s not subtle. Its tagline is \u201CThere\u2019s a sucker born every minute. But they don\u2019t grow up thinking they can be con men. They get taught to be one.\u201D And its trailer goes on to say, \u201CThe housing bubble was about to burst\u2026 And a group of misfits saw it coming. Now these unlikely heroes must band together and bring down the greedy villains who crashed the world economy\u2026 Before anyone else gets hurt.\u201D
Unfortunately, that last part is not hyperbole. The actions of unscrupulous financial engineers \u2014 colloquially known as \u201Cbankers\u201D \u2014 led directly to the Great Recession in 2008, which cost millions their jobs and homes, while triggering widespread deflation and anemic growth throughout much of the developed world for years thereafter.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Theory of Everything" Is a Touching Biopic of Stephen Hawking
"Bridge of Spies" Is a Masterful Cold War Thriller

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`With the specter of mutually assured destruction looming over every global crisis and proxy conflict, the Cold War is perhaps one of the most fraught periods in history. There are no heroes in this period\u2014just two paranoid superpowers scrambling to maintain the upper hand, irrespective of cost. The inherent darkness and moral ambiguity of that period makes for fantastic fodder for any storyteller looking to immerse their audience in a stark world where there are no easy answers.
The 1980s was a peak moment in that tension\u2014from Reagan\u2019s \u201Cevil empire\u201D speech and constant saber-rattling, to the U.S.-backed Contra War against Communist rebels in Nicaragua and an escalation of tensions between NATO and the USSR all around the globe. In brief: It was not a good time to be alive if you believed in world peace. Thankfully, Hollywood had spies as intrepid as Tom Hanks ready to leap into action against those dastardly Soviet Commies whenever they needed someone captured or rescued from behind enemy lines.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Chvrches' 'Love Is Dead' Is a Pop Gem

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In today\u2019s musical landscape, popular electronic music has taken over the pop world. But there are still some great pop albums that aren\u2019t filled with auto-tune and EDM drops.On May 25th, the Scottish band Chvrches released their third album called \u201C Love is Dead.\u201D The synth-pop band has lots of happy vibes and catchy hooks on their new album. It\u2019s a pleasant listen but might not be what you expect if you only know them from their first two albums. The band took a left turn creatively, covering topics like technology, isolation and death rather than dancing around in your bedroom to this record.
Chvrses has gained more popularity among a different group of fans by releasing this album than they ever did with their first two releases combined. This is partially because they have expanded their audience by collaborating on songs with Haim and Bleachers recently as well as making this change in sound so now they have crossover appeal to radio listeners too!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
